comments.commentBody: I like this column.  I too dreamed of foreign lands, growing up in India, and visited some of these lands.  I wrote about these lands too. I think my imagination serves me well but nothing can beat the experience of being there, first hand. However, I like the idea of developing writing in any form, based on photographs, diaries and objects.  Its another way to write. I use both forms - imagination and first hand experience - to write and like them both.

The second-largest investor in Pox news is a Saudi prince who has no interest in stable, logical American government. But he does have a lot of oil he needs to sell.
By the same token, the new British exec at the Times has no interest in publicizing BP's many offenses against social and environmental responsibility.
These biases do not reflect prejudice, but self-interest.

Two books, both by Jared Diamond, illuminate the central issues here.
They are: "Guns, Germs and Steel" and, apropos to the climate crisis approaching, "Collapse", or how nations choose to fail or succeed.
page 86 of "Guns, etc." explains why economies of large nations must be redistributive rather than merely reciprocal.
No, Mr. West is right on.
States rights!

First as a liberal in the true 18th century (Whig) mentality I believe insanity cannot be prevented by post hoc legislation against the instruments of unlawful violence. I want my fellow citizens to be able to responsibly own weapons. A high capacity semi-automatic rifle Yes. A 50 caliber 500 rounds a minute chain gun... No!
Am I making what I believe a reasonable albeit arbitrary distinction? ; Yes guilty as charged.

I would be against a mentally challenged or temporarily unbalanced person from having a front loading musket. If local responsible gun owners and sellers would evidence a small amount reasonable compromise we can put into place a national framework which would respect their rights to bear arms and provide us all with the necessary assurances that weapons are owned lawfully and responsibly.

Hi David
You are right in understanding that the Second Amendment was written about the regulation and funding of local militias - concerns which are totally irrelevant today. However, despite some conservative rhetoric, we have a living Constitution - even aside from the amendment process, the interpretation of the text changes over time to meet the needs and understandings of new generations.
The interpretation of the Second Amendment is an example of how this works: at the time it was written, and up until quite recently, it was understood to be about militias - if individuals were permitted to own guns, it wasn't because of any constitutional right, it was simply because nobody wanted to take them away. Then, recently, the amendment was reinterpreted to refer to personal self defense, instead of militia service, and that is how the matter stands now. And in fact, this seems to reflect the general view of the American people, so as a constitutional issue, it makes sense.
We might wish that people thought differently about how self-defense works, but that is a different question.
Talking about old-time militias would only be relevant if you were arguing with someone who was a real fanatic about the "original intent" of the writers of the Constitution. The modern argument should probably not be about whether a person has a right to a gun, but about whether they really want one, or whether they are being manipulated by the fear-generating PR machine of the gun industry.

I like to visit New York but no way would I want to live there. Too many crazy regulations dictating how people should live their lives. I prefer Nevada where the state stays largely out of your personal life.
There is nothing wrong with North Carolina gun laws.
Arming the populace has been shown to reduce all types of criminal behavior? Please tell me where I can read said study...
It's a magazine not a clip.

The intent of this law was to ban semiautomatic handguns as few manufactures make a 7 round magazine. They hoped as a a result it would be a de facto handgun ban circumventing the Constitution. The uber liberals in NYS thought it would be a win win! Not!
Comforting to know that ducks face better odds than human beings!

I really don't understand the reluctance to uphold the clip limit.  I don't understand the NRA's resistance since there is already a "number of bullets" restriction in the federal statutes.  When you hunt for ducks the Migratory Bird Treaty Act requires that you have a plug in your automatic shotgun so that you cannot load more than three shells.  The Reason:  So you don't kill too many ducks at one time before reloading.  Really!  So the government can restrict the number of bullets to limit the duck slaughter but try to limit the number of bullets to limit people slaughter and you have violated everything that the founding fathers meant this country to be about.   True insanity.

It is millions. Roughly 4 million people have enrolled under the Medicaid expansion that is part of the ACA. Also, everyone forgets that at least 3 million young adults under the age of 26 have been able to enroll under their parents' plan. This was one of the first provisions of the ACA to take effect, and it afforded peace of mind to a lot of families.
A revealing parallel may be drawn with the exorbitant expenditures Rome expended on pursuit of pirates and terrorists leading up to the collapse.

oh boy....are you in for a surprise in the next year. you think that Wall Street is going to let you walk away with what you have? they have been steadily moving out the past three months. Get ready for your 401K to become a 101K in 2014......

This is good news for most working Americans we will have to depend on a defined contribution plan to fund our retirements.  It's hard to believe that just a few years ago we were talking about how 401K plans became 201K plans.  In just four years those plans should be much higher in value assuming employees continued to invest new contributions during that period.  Equity markets can't continue to rise this much each year obviously, but it has reaffirmed my confidence that long term investing in stocks is the best way to build sufficient capital for retirement.
Yep, that has been a problem with our insurance system for years.
She is legally dead. The insurance company in question does not have to cover her "treatment". The hospital, its patients, and the taxpayers will have to cover the costs associated with her case.
Your faith in 'government' is admirable, but misplaced.
Coolhunter - So what do you put your faith in?  For profit insurance companies who will cancel you or deny you care when you need it most?
It's a beginning. Let's hope it succeeds and that we all work together to improve it. It's the right thing to do.
And what did the uninsured have before the ACA? There were wheels but no wagon.

Should Old Acquaintance be forgot,
and never thought upon;
The flames of Love extinguished,
and fully past and gone:
Is thy sweet Heart now grown so cold,
that loving Breast of thine;
That thou canst never once reflect
On Old long syne.
CHORUS:On Old long syne my Jo,
On Old long syne,
That thou canst never once reflect,
On Old long syne.

HAPPY NEW YEAR!!!
Then we'd no doubt have an entire article about cellophane wrappers.

I think most musicians are not terribly bothered by the occasional cough or sneeze.  Some behavior, however, really can and should be controlled - for example, cell phones ringing, or noisily trying to take a seat after a program has begun.  And not only musicians get annoyed.  When I lived in Germany, noisy audience members were more likely to be scolded by fellow patrons rather than performers.

That too can have its limitations.

My 'Parsifal' CD set with Knappertsbusch & Bayreuth was recorded live, and is riddled with coughing!

But it's the best set so I bravely try to ignore those rude interruptions.

It is not the fact that some people sometime just can't suppress a slight cough that disturbs me. On the other hand I get highly distracted during a concert by people talking or playing with their pearl necklaces or other jewelry right behind me. Between movements I tend to make that displeasure - in a polite way - very clear to the offending party and always receive thanks from others around me.

Having a wonderful collection of records to listen to at home, I am not willing to pay a little fortune to hear a live concert by one of my favourite orchestras - the Berlin or Israel Philharmonic et al under the baton of the greatest conductors - only to be disturbed by others treating it like a must-be-seen-society tea-party.

Well, not always. But I take your point. Or are you being ironic?

Seriously, overheated rhetoric is not going to help our cause.
Coughing is merely the mindless territorialism inflicted by the bored listener. A pathetic way to assert their primacy over the enjoyment of a captive audience.
Good and thank you.
Ok, so I get the fisheye if I cough AND if I leave to avoid being a coughing annoyance?  Fine, I'll spend my money elsewhere.

See the next article in this series about the sounds of unwrapping cough drops. Most people work on the theory of pulling the bandaid off very slowly. And they always sit right behind me.

Seriously, if you're sick stay home. No one that needs a suppressant ought to be imposing themselves on others.
